content: When Norwegian Intelligence tried to recruit a source in Arkhangelsk in 2014, it used the email kurkovvladislav@gmail.com. (This later turned into the Frode Berg case.) When Russia’s SVR tried to recruit a source in Oslo in 2017, it used the email address alstek@mail.com.

Last week, I looked at NCSC’s cybersecurity guidance for high-risk individuals. The agency suggested using a social media service for shared accounts. Here, I say more about how delegating access to email, social media may make your accounts less secure. https://t.co/Pg8AHYMIJE

Since Apple is now notifying even more victims of spyware, let me resurface this article about Apple's Lockdown Mode, an opt-in iOS/iPadOS/macOS feature to defend against such attacks. https://t.co/rBEsn8dRqH
The UK recently published cybersecurity guidance for high-risk individuals, so I took a look. Here’s what’s good and what’s missing.👇 https://t.co/dOf2fOfcmh

I may be a little late to the whole debate about passkeys, but I am so confused by Google’s decision to remove the option to add a “regular” security key for two-factor. Only option now is passkey on a security key with a PIN. 🧐
Online sleuths have been trying to identify these bottles for a few years now. If you happen to recognize either of the logos, I'd love to hear from you! https://t.co/ihq7fOTMC1

This year’s Norwegian threat and risk assessments state that activists, dissidents, and refugees in Norway are likely to be targeted by authoritarian regimes in 2024. I wrote about what else high-risk communities should take away from the three reports. https://t.co/ZQ9oZdK1Y0

The 2024 risk assessment from the Norwegian National Security Authority includes some details on the financial impact of cyber attacks in 2019, 2021, and 2023. Hydro in 2019 would eventually approach $71 million. https://t.co/2O94NdaBf2

In 2021, two Norwegian journalists covering conditions for migrant workers in Qatar were detained for 30+ hours. Their equipment was seized, photos and videos deleted. I wrote about what this can teach us about digital security and source protection. https://t.co/2RpTiSDgpI

Google created the Advanced Protection Program to help high-risk individuals keep their accounts secure. The program is great (I’ve used it for years!), it’s just a shame the company rarely mentions it. https://t.co/teSTUxjfHv

Last year I contributed to a report with recommendations for @CISAgov’s High-Risk Community Protection initiative with @thedarktangent, @RachelTobac, and the rest of the Technical Advisory Council. You can read that report here. https://t.co/o8zfyCFudj https://t.co/vsvZPL99Pc

In 2022, @NRKno published a series of articles about a Kazakh doctor with a long history of botched surgeries in a small town in Norway. After losing his authorization to operate there, Jerlan Omarchanov moved to Germany where he still operates today. https://t.co/iiMQp4KdOY

I wrote about how the Norwegian National Security Authority has supported elected officials, political parties, and non-profit organizations since early 2017. Operation Pro Bono convinced a non-profit board to approve the implementation of two-factor auth. https://t.co/KBdc5lASoN

A woman was found dead in Isdalen, Norway in 1970. No one knows who she is. Last month, I obtained records through the Freedom of Information Act which show how the FBI tried to assist with identifying the unmarked cosmetics found in the woman’s luggage. https://t.co/fZOxsc2Dds

Thanks to @splunk’s @audrastreetman and Madeleine Tauber for hosting me on The Security Detail podcast! We talked a lot about digital threats against civil society and at-risk people, including defending against attacks w/spyware w/Apple’s Lockdown Mode. https://t.co/msoyZmbgKk

ICYMI @adfichter has published a three-part series on surveillance and spyware in Switzerland. For her third and final article, we talked about NSO Group's Pegasus tool and how victims, such as journalists and lawyers, have no recourse, even in Europe. https://t.co/O5QyUn5R86
Looking for someone familiar with FOIA in Estonia, please DM or email me!

This interview with @SecurityWeek was done almost two years ago, but just published last week. We talked about different aspects of security research, including my goal to have fun with the projects I take on — like the gun hack in 2015. https://t.co/MWKibq8Qpj

An unidentified woman was found dead in Isdalen near Bergen, Norway in November 1970. Police found a notebook with her belongings. Maybe something for @CryptoVillage next year? Anyone else interested in this? (See “The Isdal Woman,” “Death in Ice Valley.”) https://t.co/mwzQI1Odjk https://t.co/cOHMWloUag

I’ve focused on security for at-risk civil society groups for over a decade now (🙀), including human rights defenders, lawyers, and journalists. I’m available for collaboration, consulting, and presenting next year, please get in touch if you’d like to work together!

I know this is a long shot, but if you know the family in this photograph please get in touch! My guess is the photo is taken in Oslo around 1991, the family may be based in Chicago. https://t.co/rC0mOHLYHN

Since @citizenlab, @accessnow, @AmnestyTech, and @ShareConference uncovered use of spyware against two members of civil society in Serbia, let me resurface this article about Apple's Lockdown Mode, an opt-in iOS feature to defend against such attacks. https://t.co/rBEsn8dRqH

I wrote a piece for @bindinghook on the many ways journalists and civil society organizations have sounded the alarm on spyware this last decade, and how very little is done to counter the growing threat. https://t.co/7eu4Po8ruH

In “Nadia Comăneci and the Secret Police: A Cold War Escape,” historian Stejărel Olaru details the relationship between sports and politics in Communist Romania. The book mentions a journalist and informant named Aurel Neagu, code name 'Constantin.' https://t.co/EwXCOcvCZ1

Phil Geyelin was a Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist and @washingtonpost editor. Geyelin passed away in 2004, and the FBI recently released his file in response to my FOIA request. You can view all the documents here. https://t.co/dJaBr0rcp9
I wrote about U.S. efforts to counter the misuse and proliferation of commercial spyware, and NSO’s continued outreach to government officials. https://t.co/eumkZFYNJX

I looked at address confidentiality programs across the US and found 11 states offering protection to abortion providers, patients, and family members. The majority expanded their programs after the Supreme Court's decision to overturn Roe v. Wade in 2022. https://t.co/qhRuFSEOoH

The first episode of The Billionaire, the Butler and the Boyfriend includes an interview with @edwyplenel, the co-founder of @Mediapart. Plenel was targeted with NSO Group’s Pegasus spyware in 2019. (Likely unrelated to this documentary.) https://t.co/Fo4Iii1l3K

Excited to start @azamsahmed’s book about a woman avenging the death of her daughter by the Zeta drug cartel. Ahmed is the former New York Times bureau chief in Mexico, and may also have been targeted with Pegasus for his reporting in the region. https://t.co/mWHEypC8sk

A lot has been reported about China's growing cyber capabilities and implications for a potential invasion of Taiwan. But what do we know about how China targets civil society abroad? As it turns out, quite a bit. https://t.co/0Ic7yxpWrM

An espionage scandal has been brewing in Denmark ever since @Snowden revealed connections to the US intelligence apparatus. Now an intelligence chief and a former minister face trials for disclosing state secrets. Article by @harryfoxdavies, h/t @thegrugq. https://t.co/gGda4jOMSa

NSO Group has long argued that its Pegasus spyware is designed to help governments protect human lives from crime and terror. Glad to hear @NiAolainF discuss how new technologies used for counterterrorism affect human rights on today's Lawfare Podcast. https://t.co/5mknD02G2h
@neueSonne198 @NiAolainF Do you have another source saying the cartels used Pegasus against journalists?

In an article for @bindinghook on the dangers of spyware, @SophieintVeld writes "it is up to the press to keep the fire burning until more politicians wake up to the danger." Worth noting that journalists and researchers have done so for a decade already. https://t.co/1JzRkM5CLf https://t.co/uwEQKJTo1r

In December 2020, @citizenlab reported that 36 journalists with @AlJazeera had been hacked with Pegasus. The attacks were attributed to Saudi, UAE, and two unknown operators. Here's what one victim said about how/why the newsroom suspected a compromise. https://t.co/2v9jhidlRk https://t.co/HiQXqvPKVP

There’s been an increase in spyware cases in Armenia over the last two years, according to @CyberHubAm. Apple recently sent out new alerts to people there too, saying their devices may be targeted by state-sponsored actors. Lockdown Mode should help.  https://t.co/rBEsn8dRqH

If you received a message from Apple saying state-sponsored attackers may  be targeting your iPhone, please turn on Lockdown Mode on your phone. It is the best defense we have against sophisticated spyware like Pegasus and Predator. https://t.co/szXKjYsOjw

Apple recently told a number of people that state-sponsored actors may be targeting their iPhones, including journalists and politicians in India. I wrote about four things you should know about Lockdown Mode; the best defense we have against spyware. https://t.co/rBEsn8dRqH

Last month, I had the pleasure of giving the keynote presentation at the @MITREattack conference in D.C. The talk focused on security for civil society and what sophisticated spyware means for us as defenders. You can watch the recording here! https://t.co/ossMziLvsn

In 2016, @citizenlab reported that Pegasus facilitated persistence by disabling Apple's automatic updates. This 2018 article by @iblametom suggests the spyware used the same tactic when targeting @GhanemAlmasarir that summer. https://t.co/cSzLLTkYnv https://t.co/UNH5BBKhBO

Daniel Lizárraga, the former editor of @_elfaro_, was expelled from El Salvador in July 2021. Interesting to note that @citizenlab found he was last infected with Pegasus on or around July 8--the day El Faro published a statement about his expulsion. https://t.co/Qa3BSpNieC

Omar Abdulaziz got a Pegasus infection link hours after placing an order on Amazon in June 2018. Lucky guess by the UAE operator or crafted with intelligence from, say, malware? When Artemis Seaford was targeted in 2021, the SMS used info from wiretap. https://t.co/QKiuidDbz0 https://t.co/4KQY1TRp3N

In 2017, Panama's former president was arrested on surveillance and embezzlement charges. According to the indictment, Ricardo Martinelli used Pegasus to spy on politicians, legislators, and journalists. Were any of the victims named publicly? https://t.co/4YnX595IYT

Last week, @SophieintVeld proposed a second inquiry into commercial spyware. If it's not Pegasus or Predator, it'll be something else. Look at Ahmed Mansoor, since 2011, he's been targeted with spyware from FinFisher, Hacking Team, DarkMatter, and NSO. https://t.co/IuJMXPgaXY

U.S. Senator Robert Menendez allegedly agreed to use his position to benefit Egypt in exchange for hundreds of thousands of dollars of bribes, inc personalized swag and gold bars. The indictment includes photos, even! https://t.co/HpKho89TOn https://t.co/j0QWKhSbtu

On October 9, @AmnestyTech wrote about a Predator operator using social media to share infection links. I just remembered we've seen this with Pegasus too, as documented by @citizenlab in 2016. The post with the infection link is still live. https://t.co/SoNZKx8rcW https://t.co/lv8HFxxqFt

My latest post for Journalist and Spy: Sefton Delmer was a journalist turned propagandist for the British government during the Second World War. An internal MI5 memo describes him as “a worldly, shrewd, suave individual with considerable charm.” https://t.co/ayaRPhkWsM

Another takeaway from my talk at @MITREattack on Tuesday: Apple’s Lockdown Mode is the best defense we have today against Pegasus and Predator. I’m not aware of a device being compromised with this mode enabled. https://t.co/QJkIBACRd4

In my @MITREattack talk today, I highlighted that at-risk communities don’t always have technical people translating your APT reports for them. So when you write, write for them too—and include the mitigations they should be aware of.

The September 13 meeting summary for @CISAgov’s cybersecurity advisory  committee includes a blurb about the recommendations from the technical advisory council re: the agency’s work to protect high-risk communities. https://t.co/fdPtos5QGI https://t.co/mXDDD8Oq2w

Thanks again to @MITREattack for a great ATT&CKcon and for inviting me to give the opening keynote today. The recording will be on YouTube at some point, in the meantime you can view my slides here. https://t.co/86EmoTRxFg

Wrapped up two days of inspiring meetings with the @AspenInstitute in Singapore, then went on a tour of Little India, the Malay District, and Chinatown. Heading home with more ideas for my work with at-risk people and civil society groups. https://t.co/mOFG8XZym0

At least 57 people have been targeted with Predator since 2021. The operators are in Egypt, Greece, and Vietnam. A few of the targets in @AmnestyTech's latest report seem a bit random too, e.g. @AlbGob, @AnarchoTerran, and @MarioNawfal. https://t.co/LE0pHIIwlb

I’ve read a bunch of reports about the Pegasus and Predator spyware since 2016. One topic that’s often missing is whether the targeting of government employees might violate UN norms of responsible behavior in cyberspace. I think it would apply since the operator is a government.

One takeaway from @AmnestyTech's latest report on the Predator spyware is that the Vietnamese operator isn't too worried about getting caught. Sending links on X and Facebook is riskier than the direct targeting we've seen elsewhere with other operators. https://t.co/uxJQ4hAq04

In late 2021, Meta said it removed 300 accounts on Facebook and Instagram linked to Cytrox, maker of the Predator spyware. Meta identified Vietnam as a Cytrox customer. This year, @AmnestyTech found a Vietnam operator using X and Facebook to target 50 accounts with Predator.

Timeline of Pegasus zero-click first reported v. seen in the wild: 2013 brochure mentions the infection vector, which @citizenlab reported in 2016; @lorenzofb and @josephfcox reported a source seeing a demo in 2018; in 2020, @citizenlab reported seeing it in the wild in 2019.

Finished the first draft of my slides for the @MITREattack conference next week! Topic is civil society, spyware, and our role as defenders. No memes, but did include two photos of my cat. Looking forward to seeing everyone there! 🥳 https://t.co/PCwmIh4lOE

In 1957, the Daily Express wrote about a new miniature camera for use by Soviet spies. A senior MI5 counter-terrorism official followed up with an internal memo suggesting the press be told "to make no mention of secret intelligence and counter-intelligence methods." https://t.co/0nZQREaFk7

Really looking forward to giving the opening keynote at the @MITREattack conference later this month! If there’s anything specific you’d like to hear me talk about, let me know. Thinking civil society and sophisticated spyware.

Earlier this week, Members of the European Parliament voted *against* an amendment to scrap the right to surveil journalists in the European Media Freedom Act. Good thing @AmnestyTech, @citizenlab, and others continue to work with spyware victims. https://t.co/XdPxXVbQ3w

Big thanks to @triketora for creating @privacypartyapp because idk who actually keeps track of all the possible privacy settings on sites like Facebook, Instagram, and X. The browser extension and playbooks make it easy to review and update your settings. https://t.co/zbESB3HmYa

When announcing the #PredatorFiles, @AmnestyTech noted that Intellexa "advertises itself as an 'EU-based and regulated company.'" In June, I wrote about North Macedonia endorsing a new human rights initiative while allowing development of the spyware. https://t.co/L6JS4clmm4

Took a freediving course in Florida this past weekend! Static breath hold for 1 min and 40 sec, best dive was 18ft for 21 sec. There’s a bunch of new info to take in and apply, but I can see why people get hooked. Big thanks to the team at @livefreediving! ❤️🤿 https://t.co/NRSMO0cVN9

My latest post for Journalist and Spy is about Richard Gott, former Latin America correspondent and features editor for the @guardian. In 1994, KGB defector Oleg Gordievsky alleged that Gott had been an "agent of influence" for Soviet intelligence. https://t.co/Vk2KcjdxON
Been a while since I built a mechanical keyboard, but finally completed a very, very late birthday gift. Used KBD75v2 from @KBDfans with linear switches from @MekaniskCo. https://t.co/vsmpbREtbH

Last week, @citizenlab reported that Ahmed Eltantawy was targeted with Predator in 2021 and attributed the attack to Egypt. That's the third known case of targeting using the spyware by the authorities that year. https://t.co/toJ5cqQUeE

In January, @documentonews published a list of 117 individuals monitored by the Greek intelligence service using traditional wiretaps and the Predator spyware. It's not clear if all were spied on with Predator. If anyone's got insight, please get in touch! https://t.co/6sgaJl0Onu

Meanwhile in Ireland, @BarryAndrewsMEP has asked the Justice Committee to investigate the presence of Intellexa Limited. The request comes a month after the spyware maker was blacklisted by the U.S. government. https://t.co/kcRO4eNGUv

Ever wondered what the Predator spyware costs? Leaked documents published last year say $8,000,000 for a package of 100 successful 1-click infections with 10 running at the same time. More in this episode from @DarknetDiaries. https://t.co/ETpr4dItXG

Days after the U.S. launched the Export Controls and Human Rights Initiative to address spyware in Dec 2021, a company hired by NSO to advise on human rights matters emailed the UK Foreign Office saying NSO “has much to contribute to policy discussions.” https://t.co/mhFXFhNaBs

According to @MadaMasr, the phone of an aspiring presidential candidate in Egypt was targeted with Predator. Analysis by @citizenlab found Ahmed Tantawi was targeted “in the period between May and September 2023.” https://t.co/6j4dsq9Pud
I'm building a public dataset of victims of the Predator spyware. If you've followed the scandal in Greece and see names I've not yet added, please let me know! https://t.co/LE0pHIIwlb

In July, @e_triantafillou and @telloglou reported on the 200+ text messages linked to the Predator spyware by the Greek data protection authority. Unsurprisingly, a handful of them impersonate news media, including @CNN and @CNNgreece. https://t.co/zUmEYAQiIx https://t.co/sD6faWAg1z

In July 2021, Dutch crime reporter Peter R de Vries was shot and killed in Amsterdam. In this podcast series about Europe’s cocaine crisis, @ProjectBrazen looks into his murder; the cartel leaders and the cops; and the other victims caught in the middle. https://t.co/PwWsrSAOEB

Kudos to @josephfcox for pushing @Microsoft on this issue; given how popular Skype is with civil society and at-risk individuals, I'm surprised the company first said the bug did not require immediate servicing. https://t.co/ypkTyeVgsw
A six-month investigation by the @KyivIndependent, @LHreports, and other media partners looked at why Europe is struggling to ramp up ammunition production. https://t.co/kRjKEWork8

A China-aligned espionage group developed a custom version of the Signal messaging app and distributed it through the Google Play store. The app, Signal Plus Messenger, used Signal's "Linked Devices" feature to link the victim's device to the attacker's. https://t.co/OZC94K5fex

Sandworm strikes again, this time using Android malware to target devices used by the Ukrainian military. The malware analysis report from @CISAgov and partners mentions use of Tor for access to/from infected devices. https://t.co/IVjE9Kbfn4

Good article by @KimZetter here about yet another press freedom case in the U.S., this time involving a journalist who shared un-aired clips from Fox News' 2022 interview with Kanye West. https://t.co/N6LTwm3Av2

Sylvia Rafael was a South African Mossad agent who posed as a freelance photographer named Patricia Roxenburg. She was arrested in Norway in 1973 after the Mossad killed the wrong man, mistaking the victim for a high-ranking member of Black September. https://t.co/RtmvXfLTG3

One of Norway's leading newspapers, VG, created a transparency portal to help readers understand how the reporting process works--including choices made by editors and corrections made to published stories. https://t.co/xUXLU9a8gW
For a little bit of hacker history, check out the records I recently got from the FBI about @CrewSub7 and @xillwillx. https://t.co/Lzw2laYj0O

Latest @CrimeJunkiePod episode has interesting details about the capture of Rex Heuermann, also known as the Gilgo Beach Killer. Police relied on call metadata and cell tower pings to link his phone to a burner phone he was also using at the time. https://t.co/OCR3NOVh9R

Norwegian National Security Authority    shared details about the supply chain attack disclosed this morning: a zero day in Ivanti Endpoint Manager, used by the Government Security and Service Organization (DSS). https://t.co/TYLWVCGUOn

Brazil has rejected a request by the United States to extradite Sergei Cherkasov, the alleged Russian spy who studied in Washington, D.C. and last year sought an internship with the International Criminal Court in The Hague. https://t.co/nS7qNhhGOW

Robert Moore is a TV producer turned private spy, and the subject of a new podcast from @tortoise called Into The Dirt. In 2012, K2 Intelligence hired Moore to spy on activists, a job he did for four years while posing as a journalist and filmmaker. https://t.co/RQ3Q4lmfNH

Norwegian authorities disclose wide-spread supply chain attack, says the police and National Security Authority are still investigating. No word on who or what or when just yet. https://t.co/FGKe0ksZ7g
Greece’s independent Data Protection Authority found that at least 92 individuals have been targeted with the Predator spyware, including @ArtemisSeaford. https://t.co/T7bEM1V2xQ
The guides from @FreedomofPress are now available in Spanish and outline privacy/security settings in both @signalapp and @WhatsApp. https://t.co/9iuGcaxUDt
New investigation by @insidestory_gr and @IrlMacedonia takes a closer look at Intellexa and its Predator spyware, and the relationship between Greece and North Macedonia. https://t.co/YoWTTvqabS
Do I know any journalists in Taipei who would be interested in in-person security training later this year? Send an email to runa@granitt.io or DM me.

Last year, the Spanish government said prime minister Pedro Sánchez and defense minister Margarita Robles had been infected with the Pegasus spyware. Now Spain's High Court is closing its investigation due to lack of cooperation from NSO Group. https://t.co/pcR5Cr3ADX

In United States v Roman Sterlingov, the government recently said it has “particularly deep” concerns about testimony by Jonathan Scott, one of the experts hired by Tor Ekeland for Sterlingov’s defense. Scott is known to intentionally publish inaccurate, misleading information. https://t.co/IjUOSEB4Jx

If you're coming to the NYC premiere of @YouTubeEffect tomorrow and already know you have great questions for @Winter, @PeterjNicoll and @cagoldberglaw, let me know! Really looking forward to the screenings and the Q&As afterwards. https://t.co/uql2NzIaaU

And in Morocco, @NaimiAbdessamad claims Jonathan Scott is an expert on all things cyber and crime, despite his well-documented habit of producing and sharing incorrect and misleading work in blog posts and social media for over two years. Didn’t even spell his name right. https://t.co/YdICjSsk97
@amansxcodes @NaimiAbdessamad @maldr0id That's not my article. My work can be found here. I suggest you take a moment to catch up. Happy to chat more after that. https://t.co/HtZ07tVcH7

@0xThi3f Appreciate the input, though I believe there's a need to fact-check and call out misinformation when it reaches new and larger audiences. If he didn't land in our space, he likely would've found another one--just like his move from bug bounties to spyware.

“I ignore the experts telling me that I’m wrong, so therefore I’m right” is a fairly common argument by both Jonathatn and Irina. Big thanks to @maldr0id for documenting misinformation claims in cybersecurity here. https://t.co/3iT4PIBIct

Last month, Irina Tsukerman wrote an article for Polish state media claiming the Pegasus Project is a Russian intel op. She often shares inaccurate and misleading information, and this article is no exception. Here's a fact-check of some of her claims. https://t.co/WapfXAkztr
Really excited to give more talks this fall about security and protecting civil society, starting with @Sikkerhetsfest in Lillehammer, Norway in August. 🥳https://t.co/CPnAEd6lwI

W zeszłym miesiącu Irina Tsukerman napisała artykuł dla TVP World, w którym twierdzi, że Pegazus jest operacją rosyjskich służb. Tsukerman często publikuje wprowadzające w błąd i nieprawdziwe informacje. Oto weryfikacja niektórych jej twierdzeń. https://t.co/WapfXAkztr

If you’ve been using Twitter threads to document mis- and disinformation in cybersecurity, consider also sharing on a platform that is more friendly to not-logged-in readers and search engines. Blogs are cheap and easy.
New podcast from @tortoise is this fascinating story about a private spy allegedly turned whistleblower and all the work he’s done in the UK over the years. https://t.co/F0t9fpGcBm

Important post from @JessicaValenti about how the anti-abortion movement is seeking to change how we describe abortion bans, reframing them instead as “restrictions.” https://t.co/DoGD0i1Tye https://t.co/1e85bSt7xm
Honored to moderate the Q&A for the NYC screening of @Winter’s new doc, the @YouTubeEffect, next week! Still a few tickets available. Come say hi! https://t.co/nqbj1uA3kR https://t.co/sDtbEXpIqI
Decided to go all in and complete the tattoo sleeve I started last summer. Done by @remybtattoo again, currently a guest artist at La Manigance in Toronto. ❤️ https://t.co/PGehCrG6E0

Meanwhile in Poland: a news network aired this graphic by Irina Tsukerman illustrating the connections between @EP_PegaInquiry, @FbdnStories, and Russian Intelligence. It’s bananas. https://t.co/AePJQgJwao

Always troubling to see @jordi_canyas, a member of @europarl_en, continue to amplify incorrect and misleading information about use of spyware by/in the EU. Not to mention amplifying individuals who attack critics by misappropriating the MeToo hashtag.

Latest post for Journalist and Spy is about Hotsumi Ozaki, one of Richard Sorge's informants in Tokyo during World War II. Ozaki's first editor allegedly said his writing was hopeless, seems he was better at recruiting other reporters to Sorge's spy ring. https://t.co/tdjZyZCDh3

A FOIA request to the FBI for information on journalist Louis Kraar turned up these passport photos from 1971. Kraar began his career as a journalist for the Wall Street Journal in 1956, and later Time and Fortune. https://t.co/PJ3LcATvZD https://t.co/rPYgCSitLI

Earlier this month, @maldr0id gave a talk at @rightscon about spyware and disinformation. Among the cases he mentioned is the academic who gets their colleagues to sign onto letters of support for their cause, likely without fully understanding the issue. https://t.co/fLTF0L1YDu

Meta’s Oversight Board recommends the company “commit to preserving, and where appropriate, sharing with competent authorities evidence of atrocity crimes or grave human rights violations.” https://t.co/XfX0ffJVJH

Incredibly disheartening to see the @EUCouncil support use of spyware to target journalists, weeks after @EP_PegaInquiry concluded its work investigating use of Pegasus and Predator by/in EU member states to do just that. https://t.co/MkTjhg3NMR

Listening to a @BBCNews podcast about Lazarus and heard this about @virustotal: “databases like VirusTotal are pretty amazing, they hold samples of viruses that have been found in attacks on targets all over the world, sort of like a zoo for malware.” https://t.co/xTuBk2kRHm
Just learned the @nytimes decided to revoke subscriber access for former employees, almost four years after I left. Not sure if it also applies to gift subscriptions.

I read a book last year about people’s fascination with shipwrecks and the Titanic. The author, @DanEnRoute, is now doing some great threads re: the missing sub. Both the book and those tweets are worth a read. https://t.co/vl77h5XcOm

I've always found it interesting that NSO Group says it does not know who its customers are targeting, and at the same time definitively states that Pegasus was not used to target journalist Ben Hubbard in 2018, 2020, and 2021. https://t.co/GvaKWuH7ay https://t.co/aEib8m4VGu
I see what you did there, @SeamusHughes. https://t.co/6IBmpT1TSu

Andrew Tate has been indicted in Romania on charges of rape, human trafficking, and forming an organized crime group to sexually exploit women. If you’re curious about his background, check out this ep with @NickyWoolf and some very eloquent teenagers. https://t.co/htMBA99ifO

In 2020, @nytimes reported that a Mexican had been recruited by Russia to photograph a US source’s vehicle. Today’s story reveals the source was Aleksandr Poteyev, a former intel officer who helped the FBI with Operation Ghost Stories over a decade ago.  https://t.co/1TSzHKwTA4

Increasingly convinced all Norwegian crime authors are either former politicians, intelligence, police, or serial killers in a past life.
Thank you to @OsloFF for inviting me to speak this week! I really enjoyed the conference and feel so inspired by all the people I got to meet. Hope to see you all next year! https://t.co/yWDL7yy0ik
